# Chord: Augmented in F# (Shape: G)

## Description
The Augmented chord is a triad chord consisting of a root note, a major third, and an augmented fifth. In the key of F#, the Augmented chord is built on the note G. The notes in this chord are G (root), B# (third), and D## (augmented fifth). This chord has a distinctively sharp, bright, and dissonant sound due to the augmented fifth.

## Intervals
- Root (G)
- Major Third (B#)
- Augmented Fifth (D##)

## Genre and Flavor
The Augmented chord is commonly used in jazz, classical, and experimental music to add tension and color to compositions. In jazz, it can be used for improvisation and to create a sense of unease or dissonance in the music. Its unique sound can evoke a feeling of mystery or suspense in a piece.

## Songs
1. **"Freddie Freeloader" by Miles Davis**: This jazz standard features the use of augmented chords in the improvisational sections, adding a sense of tension and unpredictability to the music.
  
2. **"The Rite of Spring" by Igor Stravinsky**: This classical piece utilizes augmented chords to create a haunting and unsettling atmosphere, contributing to the avant-garde nature of the composition.

3. **"Tomorrow Never Knows" by The Beatles**: The outro of this iconic song includes an augmented chord, enhancing the psychedelic and experimental vibe of the track.
